prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for refusing to go to a surprise vacation paid for by my girlfriend?

Throwaway as I don’t want my girlfriend to see this post.

Just a bit of background info: my girlfriend works in HR and I work in IT for the same company, however because we work in two different branches we only really get to see each other before/after our shift as our lunch breaks are scheduled at different times. Important to note that we report to the same big boss even though we’re in different departments. Anyways, my birthday was two days ago. My girlfriend and I celebrated by going to a fancy restaurant and having a glass of wine after. Then she starts babbling about a “surprise” she has for me, and gives me an envelope. In the envelope are return flights to Switzerland, for a two-week holiday! Immediately I began to wonder how this holiday would work considering I hadn’t applied for leave, but before I could even ask, she said she talked to our boss months in advance and told him to keep it a secret. I didn’t say anything but I was really annoyed. Asking our boss for couples’ leave is just unprofessional and could jeopardize my career. Not only that, but she never asked me if I was okay with using my leave for an overseas holiday. I would much prefer using that time to relax and sleep. I was going to suggest her returning the tickets but she has already paid for everything, including ski resorts, and I figure she would incur various cancellation fees. I just believe that she should have asked me, because I do not want to travel overseas while on leave. I guess I didn’t act as enthused as she wanted me to because she asked me why I was unhappy, and I told her that I would refuse to go as she should have asked me first. She’s annoyed at me. My close friends are telling me that I’m being ungrateful and that I should just go. AITA?
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the author (AITA) is in the wrong for refusing a surprise vacation paid by his girlfriend. 

First, the setup: the girlfriend works in HR, the author in IT, both same company but different branches. They only see each other before/after shifts. Important that they report to the same big boss. 

Birthday celebration with a fancy dinner and wine. Girlfriend gives a surprise envelope with flights to Switzerland. She mentions she talked to their boss months ago to get leave approved. The author is annoyed because she didn't ask him first, didn't know about applying for leave, and he prefers to relax at home. He refuses to go, she's upset, friends say he's being ungrateful. 

The author's reasoning: he thinks it's unprofessional to have the boss arrange leave for a couples' trip without his input. Also, he didn't want an overseas trip. Friends say he should go, he's being ungrateful. 

Now, considering the AITA framework. The key points here are consent and communication. The girlfriend made a big decision (vacation, using leave, spending money) without consulting him. Even though she paid for it, the fact that she used their boss to arrange leave without his knowledge could be problematic. The author's right to refuse is his own preference, but is he in the wrong for not being grateful?

In relationships, mutual respect and communication are key. She may have thought she was doing something nice, but not discussing it first could be seen as overstepping. The author's concern about professional implications is valid—using company leave for a personal trip without prior agreement might affect his job. Also, he has different preferences for relaxation. 

On the other hand, she made a generous gesture. Refusing might seem ungrateful, but he's within his rights to set boundaries. The question is whether her actions were inappropriate by not seeking his input. 

In many cases, people expect to be involved in decisions that affect their time and work. So the author isn't necessarily in the wrong for saying no. His friends might be right about being ungrateful, but the core issue is lack of communication from her side. Therefore, the answer is B.
